Want to be a better writer? Then check out Ralph Hornbeck's 14 Rules for Pretty Good Writing. While Hornbeck admits he hasn't read many books, he says he's done the next best thing: he's absorbed lots of advice from mystery fiction's great prose stylists. https://t.co/BEKpRibkki

It is an honor to announce that stories by Scott Loring Sanders, John Wimer, William Burton McCormick @WBMCAuthor, and Jeff Soloway @jeff_soloway have been nominated for the 2022 Thriller Award for Best Short Story! Congrats to all! https://t.co/LQVdok5vEa https://t.co/fXBCmeMAwl

Does a literary life necessarily make for a lonely one? Here author Michael Caleb Tasker discusses loneliness in the fiction of Bradbury and Highsmith, as well as its possible function in the writing process https://t.co/L1NuTWuaJ0

Why do we read? Why do we write? In today's blog, Lou Manfredo asks these questions while pondering his debt to the writers who came before him—a debt he knows he can never truly repay. Read Manfredo's new story "Sundown" in our March/April issue. https://t.co/NUkxG2ma0t

The results of our 80th Anniversary Trivia Contest are in! Today we announce our winners, and give you the answers to what turned out to be a tough quiz. Thank you to all who participated! https://t.co/nSQvP4gWfs

One of our frequent contributors, Kevin Mims, follows up an essay he wrote last fall about the short fiction of Frederick Forsyth. Here Mims discusses the author's second collection of short stories, which went overlooked in the wake of 9/11. https://t.co/aIlI5LSENU

Our Jury Box columnist Steve Steinbock has been doing a lot of research for his first Japanese-to English translation to appear in EQMM. In today's blog post, he shares what makes Japanese so difficult to translate—and so fascinating.
https://t.co/cCblvGgwAy

Setting is vital to good fiction. Unlike plot or character, setting is best at placing readers into a new world uniquely wrought by the writer's imagination. Or is it? Only with the right details, according to author K.L. Abrahamson in today's blog post. https://t.co/9DfLtFuWxu

Raghu Roy has loved reading since childhood, but writing never came easily. The ebb and flow of life always pushed any ambitions to authorship aside, until two years ago. Find out here how Roy came to write his first piece of published fiction. https://t.co/iJ4MLsmJqW

Thank you to our readers for voting and to our authors for trusting us with their work! You can find out more about these stories in the current issue. Congratulations, and stay well! We hope our stories bring you many more hours of happy reading in 2020 and beyond.
Our first-place winner is David Dean for his inventive and moving historical mystery “The Duelist” (May/June 2019).

Tied for second are @PaulDMarks for “Fade-Out on Bunker Hill” (March/April 2019), an entry in his evocative series set in L.A., and Doug Allyn for his Civil War era tale “The Dutchy” (November/December 2019), a sequel to his Edgar Award winning tale “The Scent of Lilacs.”
Third place goes to @GMMalliet for her chilling and twisty story “Whiteout” (January/February 2019).
While we won't be able to gather in style this year as we usually would to celebrate, we are elated to announce the fantastic winners of the 2019 EQMM Readers Award!
